text: Olivia. Hey.
They left you in here all by yourself.

Officer Garvey came in for a minute, but she
had to go.
It wasn't that much fun anyway.
Ashley.
Did something happen? Are you okay?
Yeah. I just wanted to see you.
Didn't you have school today?
I did, then I took a cab here.

Ashley. They must have called your mother by
now.
I'm sure she's worried sick about you.
She doesn't care.
She's probably going out of her mind.
I am taking you home.
Let's go.
No, what? I wanted us to hang out today.
We can't. I'm working.
But I won't get in your way.
I promise. I can help you.
Ashley. You know how you can help me?

You can help me by never, ever doing this
again.
Do you understand that?
Now let's go. Come on. No!
Ashley! Ashley, you're bleeding.
I'm okay.
Is your mother home?
She never is.
But I wish I loved you then.
The way I love you now.
Ashley Austin Black, you get in here.
Why do you do this to me?
Let me see it.

Miss Austin, is there a place we could speak
privately?

Detective, you really shouldn't have gone out
of your way.
My driver would have picked her up.
Olivia doesn't mind. She's my friend.
It's important that we speak.
This is not a good day.
Ricky, we've only got the studio till 4:30.
We still have two tracks to lay down.

Oh, honey. Um. Look, why don't you just go in
the green room with Connie, and you have her,
uh, get you something to eat, okay.
But can I stay with you?
No, honey. Mommy's working.
Well, then can Olivia stay with me?
No. She can't.
Just go. Okay.
Thank you, detective.
Okay, let's try it again.
She calls all the time.
What happens when you have to hang up?

First, she begs to talk to us for a few more
minutes, and then when I have to go, she
just. She sounds so depressed.

When you first met, how much time did you
spend together?
Just a few minutes.
It sounds like reactive attachment disorder.

It's very common in orphans who are
abandoned during their crucial bonding cycle.

They meet complete strangers and they form
instant relationships.
So it's not just my sparkling wit.

I have one patient who meets a stranger and
she goes up and hugs them.

She goes to the market and tells the
checkout girl that she loves her.

Well, that fits, but Ashley keeps getting
hurt.

It's part of the package and it could
escalate.
Is there treatment?

I could start her on corrective attachment
therapy, but, Olivia, I'd have to see the
mother and daughter together.
It's never going to happen.

Well, if she's in imminent risk, children's
services could mandate therapy.
Olivia.
Hey, kiddo. Hey.
Hey. How you doing?
You had to come see my room.
Oh, next time, sweetheart.
No, please, just
for a minute. No, I gotta go.
Ashley, she can't come in.
Let's go.

No, no, really, sweetheart, I got to go next
time.
No. Ashley. Come inside.
No, not without Olivia.
Make her come in. She can't.
Ashley.
Ashley. Ashley, stop.
Stop, stop.
What are you doing? Give her to me.
Okay. Get her inside.
No. What's the
matter? What are you doing here?
Your daughter needs help.
I talked to a psychologist.

Who said- What? This psychologist can help
her.

The thing is, she needs to see the both of
you together.
Leave us alone, Ricky.
Your daughter needs help.
Get away before I call the police.
Miss. Austin, I am the police.
Then it's damn lucky
I have my own security.
